description: {"blocks":[{"key":"1599o","text":"This protocol details a prospective randomized placebo-controlled double blind clinical trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of CLBS03 (autologous ex vivo expanded polyclonal CD4+CD25+CD127lo/-FOXP3+ regulatory T-cells [Tregs]) in adolescents with recent onset Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":183,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":188,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":194,"length":4},{"style":"sup","offset":203,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

SCHEDULE OF STUDY ASSESSMENTS","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":33}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9hi18","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5onmp","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a2ss0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3u4mi","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bsl7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7b7fm","text":"APPENDICES","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"33hdj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a7rvu","text":"1. ADA Criteria for Diabetes Diagnosis","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":38}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cl595","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6s15k","text":"The following criteria are taken from the 2017 ADA publication on classification and diagnosis of diabetes:41","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cinc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"17q48","text":"Fasting plasma glucose (FPG) ≥126 mg/dL (7.0 mmol/L). Fasting is defined as no caloric intake for at least 8 h.∗","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":111,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cq6np","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2n7h","text":"OR","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"42s03","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8d50e","text":"2-h plasma glucose (PG) ≥200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L) during an oral glucose tolerance test(OGTT). The test should be performed as described by the World Health Organization (WHO), using a glucose load containing the equivalent of 75 g anhydrous glucose dissolved in water.* ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5duv1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7gi0p","text":"OR","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4a2fe","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6t1a6","text":"A1C ≥6.5% (48 mmol/mol). The test should be performed in a laboratory using a method that is National Glycohemoglobin Standardization Program (NGSP) certified and standardized to the DCCT assay.*","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4tmkg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"522a2","text":"OR","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"89ar9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7coul","text":"In a patient with classic symptoms of hyperglycemia or hyperglycemic crisis, a random plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL (11.1 mmol/L).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"77dgt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dcmd9","text":"Per ADA Standards of Medical Care-2017, blood glucose rather than A1c should be used to diagnose acute onset of type 1 diabetes in individuals with symptoms of hyperglycemia.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"76lhh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b6jgs","text":"∗In the absence of unequivocal hyperglycemia, results should be confirmed by repeat testing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":0,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7j1c9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"840v4","text":"2. Mixed Meal Tolerance Test","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":28}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4t2fv","text":"The mixed meal tolerance test (MMTT) measures the level of C-peptide (an amino acid which is released by the pancreas in amounts equal to insulin) and glucose. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2n559","text":"The level of C-peptide in the blood indicates how much insulin the pancreas is producing. A beverage called Boost® High Protein (HP) Nutritional Drink (a milkshake-like drink containing carbohydrate, fat and protein) will be administered. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8nuo7","text":"Boost HP will raise blood glucose levels and cause the body to release insulin, as a meal would. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6aekm","text":"In general, if a participant has a known food allergy to one or more components of Boost HP, the participant should not be enrolled and the site should notify the Sponsor/designee immediately. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"disou","text":"The MMTT should be performed by study staff adequately trained and authorized by the PI to perform the procedure including the PI, sub-investigators, or study nurses/coordinators trained in the performance of IV procedures. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fu7h","text":"The MMTT should be performed in the morning, with the first blood draw (time point) between 7:00 am and 10:00 am (when blood glucose is more likely to be within the target range). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3ugii","text":"The 4-hour MMTT should take 250 minutes to perform, and the 2-hour MMTT should take 130 minutes.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bb6e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mhfv","text":"The table below outlines the time points at which the blood sample will be taken from the subject for MMTT-stimulated C-peptide/glucose measurement.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5qci6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"74ul0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"aq063","text":"In preparation for the visit, each participant should:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5j602","text":"Fast for at least 10 hours (but not more than 16 hours) before the test. Participants should not eat or drink anything except water. This means no coffee, tea, soda, cigarettes, alcohol, or chewing gum during the fasting period.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jnj5","text":"Refrain from vigorous exercise during the fasting period.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2inof","text":"Refrain from working the night before the morning of the test.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4s9ej","text":"Discontinue taking any prescription medications that must be taken daily (guidelines on insulin use are provided below).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5q87n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9k3a0","text":"Carbohydrates should not be restricted from the diet before the test. As a general guideline, for each of the 3 days prior to the visit where a MMTT will be done, it is recommended that adolescent subjects should consume at least 150 grams of carbohydrates. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7im79","text":"Most diets include greater amounts of carbohydrates and there is no need to alter the participant’s diet unless he/she has been on a carbohydrate-restricted diet. Participants should also be instructed to drink plenty of liquids during the 3 days prior to the test.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eau3j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7ci0p","text":"Target Glucose Level at the Start of the MMTT","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":45}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fk7of","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3fd1","text":"The target glucose level at the start of the test is between 70 and 200 mg/dL. Regular insulin or short acting insulin analogues may be used up to 6 and 2 hours before the test, respectively (see below), to achieve the desired glucose level. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3kgjn","text":"The principal investigator and the study participant should discuss the individual situation for insulin administration to attain the goal of meter capillary glucose values within the range of 70-200 mg/dL at the start of the test. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"25h1e","text":"Subjects should be instructed to check their blood glucose by meter at home 2 hours before the start of the test so that marked hyperglycemia can be treated with a short-acting insulin analogue. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5lpi5","text":"Alternatively, participants who arrive at the research unit with elevated blood glucose can receive additional short-acting insulin analogues at the time of their arrival, if the test itself does not start until at least 2 hours after insulin administration and occurs before 10 a.m.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9l3er","text":"If a subject’s blood glucose is below the limit (70 mg/dL) prior to performing the MMTT, the participant should be treated according to local practice, and the MMTT should be rescheduled (within the allowed visit window).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fplsm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5m9vu","text":"Insulin Before the Test","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8ooj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"anlsa","text":"Short-acting insulin analogues (such as lispro or aspart) may be administered up to 2 hours before the test.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ua2b","text":"Regular insulin may be administered up to 6 hours before the test.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eh878","text":"Intermediate-acting insulin (such as neutral protamine Hagedorn [NPH]) may be administered on the evening before the MMTT, but not on the morning of the test. Participants managed with intermediate-acting insulin (NPH or Lente) should administer their usual dose on the evening before the MMTT, but not on the morning of the test.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bn31i","text":"Long-acting basal (such as glargine) insulin or continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion may be administered before, during and after the test as usual. Participants on glargine may take their usual injection at the appropriate time, and those on continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion may continue with their usual basal settings.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6ruh0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8fpcj","text":"IV Placement During the Test","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":28}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1j172","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9bbpm","text":"The IV should be in place for the duration of the test and must be flushed after each draw with saline solution or heparin flush.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c158j","text":"The participant should remain sitting or resting in bed quietly throughout the test until the test is completed. However, he or she may engage in quiet, nonstrenuous activities, such as reading, playing cards, or watching TV. The participant may walk to the bathroom between blood draws if necessary.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11ssm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ad2b9","text":"Boost HP to be Administered","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5qcvr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ehf0i","text":"Calculate the amount of Boost HP to be administered using the formula below. To convert from pounds to kilograms: pounds ÷ 2.2 = kg. There is no need to calculate after 60 kg, as this meets the minimum weight requirement for the full volume of 360 mL.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9eg1v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7srk8","text":"Boost HP dose= 6 kcal/kg body weight, at 1 kcal/mL to a max of 360 kcal (360 mL)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ffu06","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2l4j7","text":"Amount of Boost HP to be administered = 6 mL x ___kg = ___ mL","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":61}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"76j3t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fsrkf","text":"3. BMI z-score","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fmqfq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6r17j","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"30n86","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79afm","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":4,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"d9u2j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4fjmt","text":"4. status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"5okeo","text":"Summary","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ch7c1","text":"It is hypothesized that CLBS03 or autologous ex vivo expanded, polyclonal CD4+CD25+CD127lo/-FOXP3+ regulatory T-cells (Tregs) administered to participants with recent onset Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) will be safe and effective in preserving β-cell function. This protocol describes an exploratory Phase 2 trial to assess this therapy. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":77,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":82,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":88,"length":4},{"style":"sup","offset":97,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b8ci5","text":"Autologous, polyclonal CD4+CD25+CD127lo/-FOXP3+ Tregs will be expanded using a protocol that was established utilizing anti-CD3/anti-CD28 beads plus interleukin-2 (IL-2). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":26,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":31,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":37,"length":4},{"style":"sup","offset":46,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"aa4ha","text":"Subjects will receive target doses of 2.5 and 20 x 106 cells/kg BW, based on the results of one Phase 1 study in adults and one Phase 1 study in children, where it was demonstrated that it was feasible to reliably expand these cell numbers, and the infusions were well tolerated with potential for efficacy. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":53,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2agbh","text":"The primary objective of this exploratory study is to assess the safety and potential efficacy of CLBS03 to modify the T1DM disease course including preservation of β-cell function and improvements in measures of disease severity as compared with placebo in adolescents with recent onset T1DM.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9am8m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5rku8","text":"Clinical and Scientific Rationale","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":33}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6glj8","text":"Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":24}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7662o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bp5oe","text":"T1DM is one of the most common and costly pediatric diseases.2 It is estimated that up to 1 million Americans are living with T1DM3 and more than 18,000 children are diagnosed with T1DM annually in the US. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":61,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":130,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4dneo","text":"The incidence of T1DM has been increasing by approximately 3% annually in the US and abroad.4 Currently, the number of youth (age \u003c20 years) with T1DM is projected to increase by at least 23% by 2050.5","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":92,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":200,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1c92","text":"T1DM results from autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β-cells by islet-specific T-cells.6-8 This destructive process takes place over a period of months, before and after the onset of clinical diabetes.9 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":89,"length":3},{"style":"sup","offset":203,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4d0a3","text":"While interruption of this destructive process before disease onset can prevent clinical disease,10 cessation of autoimmune cell destruction even after disease onset provides for the possibility of clinical benefit.11","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":97,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":215,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3gkj4","text":"The importance of maintaining glycemic control in T1DM is well established in epidemiologic observations and prospective studies. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fe8q8","text":"Results from these studies demonstrated that intensive treatment slowed the loss of β-cell function (as measured by C-peptide in subjects with residual β-cell function) and maintained substantially lower mean HbA1c for 5 to 6 years while lowering the risk for development of microvascular complications.12 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":303,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4lb4g","text":"Treatments for T1DM specifically aimed at preserving residual β-cell function may allow subjects to more effectively manage their disease and prevent long-term diabetic complications. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"emoos","text":"As reported by the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT), current standards of care aim to reduce the incidence and progression of T1DM- related complications by initiating early, aggressive treatments to maintain a level of HbA1c as close to normal as possible.13","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":272,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2gdr4","text":"The Role of Tregs in T1DM","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c9gob","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f3s1u","text":"Efforts to prevent or reverse T1DM have been limited by the absence of tolerogenic drugs that can be used both safely and effectively. Relatively non-specific therapies such as anti-cluster of differentiation 3 (anti-CD3) monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) can be efficacious, but have associated side effects. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5r621","text":"Two substantial findings have emerged: first, that short-term immune regulation of T-cells can have a long-term effect on disease progression; and second, that immunomodulatory anti-T-cell agents induce a T-regulatory cell subset that is likely to be responsible for the long lived efficacy of T-cells, in both animal and human studies.14, 15","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":336,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1hc10","text":"Recently, Couri and colleagues reported that transplantation of autologous nonmyeloablative hematopoeitic stem cells in participants newly diagnosed with T1DM led to a preservation of β-cell mass and insulin-independence for up to four years.16 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":242,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"28clu","text":"This study demonstrated that immune tolerance can be regained; however, the adverse events associated with the stem cell transplant procedure were considerable. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5c4v","text":"There is mounting evidence that polyclonal Tregs have the potential to alter the course of T1DM relatively safely, as will be detailed below. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"81jcs","text":"Tregs play a central role in the protection from diabetes. Diabetes is accelerated in non-obese diabetic (NOD) mice depleted of CD4+CD25+ Treg.17, 18","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":143,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"vuvi","text":"Similarly, removal of proliferative signals necessary for Treg development or survival, such as IL-2, exacerbates diabetes in NOD mice.18 Recently, Bettini et al., and Tang et al. showed that the number and function of Treg cells were perturbed in NOD mice,19, 20 and transforming growth factor- β (TGF-β) was reduced.19 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":135,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":257,"length":6},{"style":"sup","offset":318,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75p8s","text":"D’Alise et al. identified defects in Treg transcripts in locations associated with diabetic pathogenesis in NOD mice (lamina propria and pancreatic lymph node).21 Experimental work suggests that therapies that augment the number or function of Tregs have beneficial effects on the progression of T1DM. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":160,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4jrrd","text":"Grinberg-Bleyer et al. found that IL-2 reverses established diabetes in NOD mice by a local effect on pancreatic Tregs.22 Tang et al. showed that infusion of Tregs into NOD mice will prevent disease onset and even reverse diabetes in mice with hyperglycemia.23 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":119,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":258,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"g557","text":"Finally, the safety of the polyclonal Tregs—a primary consideration in designing the clinical development plan—has been demonstrated in T1DM,24, 25 and in graft-versus-host disease (GvHD).26","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":141,"length":6},{"style":"sup","offset":188,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"db33t","text":"Clinical adoptive transfer of polyclonal expanded Tregs—selected and expanded in a method comparable or similar to the manufacturing process planned for CLBS03—was evaluated in two Phase 1 clinical trials, with one trial in adults with T1DM and one trial in children with T1DM. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a6gh2","text":"Doses up to 40 x 106 cell/kg body weight (BW) were administered to the adult population, and up to 30 x 106 cells/kg BW were administered to children younger than 18 years old. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":19,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":106,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"723sr","text":"These two clinical trials provided evidence of tolerability and safety of adoptive expanded polyclonal Tregs transfer in both adults and children with T1DM.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e1kto","text":"Given the potential impact of benefit, observed through efficacy biomarkers, the two clinical trials support further evaluation of CLBS03 in this disease population. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7vcs9","text":"Details of the two Phase 1 clinical trials will be discussed in Step 4 below, and are also detailed in the CLBS03 Investigator’s Brochure (IB).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ahajr","text":"Description of Investigational Product","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":38}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8okss","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8j0m","text":"Tregs, consitituting the active ingredient of CLBS03, will be isolated from the whole blood of individuals with T1DM, followed by ex vivo selection and expansion by a process based on preclinical and Phase 1 clinical experience as described in Step 4.1. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fracc","text":"These cells will be prepared using a Good Manufacturing Practice (GMP) process as described in the IB, Manufacturing.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"1d29o","text":"Non clinical Experience","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":23}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9lbtf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"53eg4","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b2v46","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mvcd","text":"In vitro studies characterizing Tregs in normal and T1DM subjects have demonstrated that sufficient numbers of CD4+CD25+CD127lo/-Tregs can be isolated from T1DM subjects, and that these cells retain the hallmarks of bona fide Tregs following the process of ex vivo expansion for 14 days.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":114,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":119,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":125,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"30cud","text":"Extensive nonclinical studies characterizing human Tregs have provided the framework for developing a robust Treg cell therapy product:","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"du0qf","text":"Analyses of human Tregs have demonstrated that selection of cells based on a combination of CD4, CD25, and CD127 (CD4+CD25+CD127lo/-) results in a highly purified population of cells that are greater than 90% FOXP3+(a transcription factor that is critical throughout life to maintain the Treg population). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":117,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":122,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":128,"length":4},{"style":"sup","offset":214,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3ubck","text":"Tregs can be readily expanded using anti-CD3 and anti-CD28-coated beads supplemented with IL-2. This expansion process has been shown to increase and restore the suppressive properties of Tregs. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dcm63","text":"Studies of human Tregs transplanted in humanized mouse models demonstrate that these cells retain their functional activity in vivo. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"en66n","text":"CD4+CD25+CD127lo/- Treg cells represent a stable, committed lineage that does not exhibit effector functions or the ability to transdifferentiate into effector cell types.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":3,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":8,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":14,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6269a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"86ptq","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c3lh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4km6l","text":"A detailed discussion of the nonclinical data outlined above is provided in the CLBS03 IB.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"30jhh","text":"Clinical Experience","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bv39j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8bbqm","text":"To date, several clinical studies have been conducted with Treg based cell therapies in T1DM, GvHD, and Crohn’s disease. The two Phase 1 studies, one study in adults with T1DM and one study in adolescents with T1DM, are discussed in detail below.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7heke","text":"US Phase 1 Trial in Adults with T1DM ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b3v0o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"982rs","text":"This was a Phase 1 prospective, open-label, uncontrolled, dose-escalating trial of autologous expanded polyclonal Tregs (investigational product manufacturing process comparable to that planned for CLBS03) in adults with T1DM (Study title: A Phase 1 Safety Trial of CD4+CD127lo/-CD25+ Polyclonal Treg Adoptive Immunotherapy for the Treatment of Type 1 Diabetes, www.clinicaltrials.gov identifier: NCT01210664) conducted by the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF) and Yale University (Yale). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":269,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":275,"length":4},{"style":"sup","offset":283,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":362,"length":22}],"data":{}},{"key":"80kir","text":"This study evaluated the safety and feasibility of autologous, expanded polyclonal Tregs in treating adults with established T1DM (onset ranging from 4.5 to 23.5 months), and is being evaluated out to 60 months.27","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":211,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"21qj1","text":"Twenty-six patients were screened, 16 met eligibility criteria and were enrolled, and 14 subjects received a single infusion of polyclonal Tregs. After signing the informed consent form (ICF), 400 mL of blood were drawn from each subject followed by separation and expansion of Tregs according the methods prospectively described in the protocol at the UCSF GMP facility. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7uei5","text":"The study involved four dosing cohorts: 1) three subjects were treated in the first dosing cohort with 5 x 106 cells, 2) three subjects were treated in the second dosing cohort with 40 x 106 cells, 3) four subjects were treated in the third dosing cohort (target dose of 320 x 106cells, average received dose of 360 x 106 cells), and 4) four subjects were treated in the fourth dosing cohort (target dose of 2600 x 106 cells, average received dose of 2700 x 106 cells). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":109,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":189,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":279,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":320,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":417,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":460,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4tvrn","text":"The highest dose represents approximately 20% of the total number of Tregs (13 x 109 cells) that are predicted to exist in normal individuals.28 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":83,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":142,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ujkp","text":"The mean follow-up at the time of data cutoff for the publication was 124 weeks (cohort 1: 182 weeks; cohort 2: 156 weeks; cohort 3: 104 weeks; and cohort 4: 78 weeks). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fb1f3","text":"The two subjects who did not receive expanded Tregs (due to failure of Treg product to meet release criteria) were not included in the data analysis.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aoe1t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3dbdj","text":"1. Safety","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6gtgu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d7g83","text":"To date, (124 weeks follow-up), a total of 144 AEs have been reported of which 4 were reported as serious. Ninety-one events were judged as mild in severity, 42 were judged as moderate, 9 were judged as severe, and 2 were judged as life-threatening. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2ftro","text":"The 11 events judged as severe or life-threatening largely reflected metabolic abnormalities of underlying diabetes. Four serious adverse events in two patients were reported: one patient had three episodes of serious hypoglycemia 14, 248, and 463 days after Treg infusion; and another patient had one episode of diabetic ketoacidosis 67 days after Treg infusion. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7qfu4","text":"No opportunistic infections or malignancies were observed. One subject developed grade 2 pharyngitis and had low-copy number CMV detected on day 7, but not detected at day 28, due to a presumed new infection with CMV occurring before receiving Treg cells. There was no apparent relationship between adverse events and Treg dose (refer to table S2 in the Bluestone et al. publication27). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":382,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"70ku8","text":"In general, administration of autologous, expanded polyclonal Tregs, comparable to CLBS03, was found to be safe and well tolerated in this Phase 1 dose-escalating trial through the mean follow-up period of 124 weeks.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"98i3n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vnt7","text":"2. Efficacy","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dc5pn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7tf9j","text":"Impact of Treg administration on MMTT-stimulated C-peptide and other indices of metabolic control (HbA1c and daily dose insulin [DDI]) was evaluated. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dkng9","text":"MMTT-stimulated C-peptide levels (measured by 4-hour area under the curve [AUC] for MMTT-stimulated C-peptide) generally remained stable over time and remained unchanged at 1 year and even after 2 years in dose cohorts 1 and 2. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4279d","text":"Three of four subjects in cohort 3 and three of the fours subjects in cohort 4 showed a decline in MMTT-stimulated C-peptide of more than 50% over 78 weeks of follow-up. DDI also appeared to be stable for almost all subjects over time and there was no apparent decrease in DDI in comparison to baseline values.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f8gs0","text":"HbA1c levels appeared to be stable over time (except for one subject whose levels went from 6.2% at screening to 12.6% at week 13), with no clear deterioration in glucose control. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1dt7g","text":"Given the small number of subjects in each cohort, the overall changes in MMTT-stimulated C-peptide in this study fall within the expected decline observed in the natural history of the disease. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bcojj","text":"However, the sample size was too small to make a clear statement about stabilization or decay in MMTT-stimulated C-peptide in treated subjects.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4272e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3138k","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5qfqq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c2ii","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"0C2CAA5305EF11EFBE540A58A9FEAC02","url":"www.clinicaltrials.gov"}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1pplq","text":"A detailed discussion of the clinical data outlined above and a list of all AEs is provided in the CLBS03 IB.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5khob","text":"Gdańsk Medical University (GMU) Phase 1 Trial in Children with New Onset T1DM","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":77}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1tj4b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"69e3u","text":"This was a Phase 1, prospective, open-label, non-randomized, parallel matched group trial of autologous, expanded polyclonal Tregs (IP manufacturing process similar to that planned for CLBS03) in children aged 5-18 years with new onset T1DM, diagnosed within the preceding 2 months.25 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":282,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9v0el","text":"The trial enrolled 12 subjects in the treatment arm, and 10 untreated control subjects matched for age, sex, and disease duration. Twenty-four months follow-up is planned, and 12 months follow-up has been completed and the results published. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2pijf","text":"The trial is being conducted at a single center at Gdańsk Medical University in Poland, and is designed to be a pilot trial to investigate safety and efficacy of Tregs. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5n057","text":"Three doses were administered based on body weight: single dose of 10 x 106cells/kg for 3 subjects, single dose of 20 x 106 cells/kg for 3 subjects, and two doses totaling 30 x 106cells/kg separated by 6-9 months for 6 subjects.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":74,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":122,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":179,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"friuc","text":"In subjects administered 2 doses, the second dose was administered to subjects with good clinical and metabolic response to the first dose of Tregs [fasting C-peptide \u003e0.4 ng/mL and/or DDI \u003c0.5 IU/kg BW], who presented symptoms of disease progression after ≥6 months of follow-up. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6m48h","text":"Protocol predefined release criteria were specified and met for all dosed subjects.24, 25","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":83,"length":6}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8u4g8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ugh3","text":"1.  Safety and Feasibility","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":26}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"93dr2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c5159","text":"There were no severe or serious AEs reported. There were no AEs suggestive of a transfusion reaction related to the administration of Tregs. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fee8u","text":"In general, administration of autologous, expanded polyclonal Tregs, similar to CLBS03, in this dose escalation trial appeared to be safe and well tolerated. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9c70d","text":"For feasibility, all planned doses for the treatment cohort met the pre-specified release criteria.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"85bi","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"27btu","text":"2.  Efficacy","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c4ha0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"25k7t","text":"In addition to safety, the primary efficacy endpoints of the trial were remission as defined as DDI ≤0.5 IU/kg, and fasting C-peptide \u003e 0.5 ng/mL 1 year after enrollment. One year after inclusion in the study, 8 out of 12 subjects (66%) still met the protocol predefined criteria of clinical remission (DDI ≤0.5 IU/kg BW) and fasting C-peptide levels \u003e 0.5 ng/mL. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"48bcg","text":"In addition, compared to the non-treated control individuals, insulin doses (DDI/kg BW) were significantly lower in Treg-treated individuals at 4 months (intermediate efficacy point) and one year after commencing the trial (primary endpoint) (p=0.04 and p=0.02, respectively). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2sv74","text":"Fasting C-peptide levels were significantly higher in Treg-treated individuals (4 months: p=0.01 and 1-year: p=0.01). HbA1c levels were the lowest in subjects treated with two doses of Tregs, intermediate in those treated with one dose and the highest in untreated individuals (p=0.01). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jhbj","text":"In addition, when data for the treated and untreated subjects were analyzed together after 4-month and one-year follow-up, it was observed that C-peptide levels correlated with percentage of Tregs in peripheral blood (4 months, p=0.04; 1 year, p=0.01). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8cueq","text":"This Phase 1 trial provides preliminary evidence supporting the safety, efficacy and biologic activity of single and multiple doses of Tregs in children with new onset T1DM, in comparison with concurrent matched controls. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"56eqc","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7aj2u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e95qm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"ee2h4","text":"A detailed discussion of the clinical data outlined above is provided in the CLBS03 IB.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ebdej","text":"Overview","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":8}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"foa6j","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9fnbf","text":"This will be a double-blinded, multi-center, exploratory trial assessing a single infusion of one of 3 treatments: CLBS03 2.5 x 106 cells/kg BW, CLBS03 20 x 106 cells/kg BW, and placebo. The study will include adolescent subjects (aged 8 to less than 18 years old) with recent onset of T1DM. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":130,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":159,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8vunn","text":"Due to potential manufacturing and processing variabilities, subjects may not receive exactly 2.5 or 20 x 106 cells/kg BW. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":108,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f39lr","text":"Subjects in the dose group referred to as 2.5 x 106 cells/kg BW will receive a dose ranging from 2 x 106 to 3 x 106 cells/kg BW. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":50,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":103,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":114,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9qmep","text":"Subjects in the dose group referred to as 20 x 106 cells/kg BW will receive a dose ranging from 2 x 106 cells/kg BW to 24 x 106 cells/kg BW depending on the manufacturing yield of Investigational Product from the subject’s blood.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":49,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":102,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":126,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"77i9t","text":"A screening visit will be conducted to determine eligibility. Subjects who continue to be eligible will be randomized prior to the blood draw at Visit 2 to manufacture the investigational product. Approximately 6 mL/kg up to 540 mL of blood will be collected. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"di361","text":"The blood will be shipped to PCT, a Caladrius Company, for manufacturing the autologous investigational product. The investigational product manufacturing takes approximately 14 days. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b7gob","text":"Once the manufacturing is completed, the investigational product will be shipped to the site for infusion, which must occur prior to product expiration. Subjects will be infused on Day 0. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3pvq","text":"Post-treatment visits will occur on days 7, 14, 28, 91, 182, 273, 364, 546, 728. There will be a total of 12 to 13 visits (including the screening and pretreatment visits).","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b98uf","text":"Approximately 111 subjects will be randomized to one of 3 treatment groups in a 1:1:1 ratio: ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6cs2t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"79lmk","text":"2.5 x 106 cells/kg BW","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":8,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4jsr","text":"20 x 106 cells/kg BW","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":7,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fkr6","text":"Placebo ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b2jbm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3guiq","text":"Randomization will be done centrally with stratification by baseline MMTT-stimulated C-peptide value. Enrollment will be completed in 2 parts. For Part 1 approximately 18 subjects will be initially randomized, at a 1:1:1 ratio, to all treatment arms. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ck644","text":"After subjects enrolled in Part 1 have reached the 28-day post-treatment visit, a safety review will be conducted. If the safety profile is deemed acceptable, enrollment in Part 2 will be allowed. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fcput","text":"An additional safety review will take place once subjects enrolled in Part 1 have reached the 3-month post-treatment visit. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7fe1u","text":"The additional subjects will be enrolled in Part 2 and randomized to all treatment arms at a ratio of 1:1:1 to reach a total enrollment of approximately 111 subjects. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"at64e","text":"A planned interim analysis will be conducted after approximately 50% of the total planned sample size have completed the Week 26 visit.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d4atg","text":"Safety, diabetes control, β-cell function, and immune function will be assessed over the course of the study. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"70gv","text":"All subjects are expected to be on intensive diabetes management (refer to Step 21) consistent with the American Diabetes Association (ADA) standard of care. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ju50","text":"Study participants’ planned visit schedule is outlined in Section 4, Schedule of Assessments.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eab1c","text":"Justification for Dose","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edjnq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3trf3","text":"CLBS03 will be administered in a single dose administration to study subjects, at dose levels of 2.5 or 20 x 106 cells/kg BW. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":111,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"40lla","text":"The lowest tested doses in the Phase 1 studies, in adults and children with T1DM, were approximately 0.1 x 106 cells/kg BW and 10 x 106 cells/kg BW, respectively. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":109,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":134,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"tuf6","text":"These were based on semi-quantitative allometric scaling of animal data, accumulated safety information from preceding clinical studies in other populations, and quantitative understanding of the Treg population in humans (Step 4 Clinical Experience). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6q5as","text":"Using an IP comparable or similar to CLBS03, up to 38.9 x 106 cell/kg BW, were evaluated in adults, and 20 x 106 cells/kg BW in children in a single administration. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":60,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":111,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8s561","text":"Additionally, 30 x 106 cells/kg BW were evaluated in children administered 2 separate doses, 6-9 months apart. In both studies all doses tested were well-tolerated, and appear to be safe, based on AE and safety laboratory analyses. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":21,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d3vlu","text":"As discussed above, preliminary mechanistic analyses from the cohorts in the above mentioned adult Phase 1 study showed no significant changes in T helper (Th) subsets, CD4+ or CD8+ effector cell differentiation, T-cell activation, B-cell subsets or monocytes. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":172,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":180,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2l9or","text":"Deuterium labeling utilized for a subset of subjects in the same study also confirmed the lineage stability of infused Tregs. Taken together, it appears that all doses tested were not associated with manifestations of Treg effector transdifferentiation that can pose a clinical safety concern. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7jk6f","text":"In the planned study, inclusion of the low dose of 2.5 x 106 cells/kg BW is to investigate a wider range of dose for this exploratory study, while supporting the available manufacturing stability data. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":59,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"af63c","text":"The high dose of 20 x 106 cells/kg BW was conservatively selected based on the highest single dose administered to  children which appears to be safe (with the 30 x 106 cells/kg BW multiple dose profile providing a safety margin), as well as accounting for manufacturing feasibility considerations. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":24,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":167,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d9s6c","text":"Hence, from a safety perspective, the 2 proposed doses appear to be safe and well tolerated.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c45h9","text":"From an efficacy perspective, the high dose is supported by the Gdańsk Medical University Phase 1 study that was conducted in children less than 18 years old, the relevant population for this study.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dlv0g","text":"In comparison to concurrent controls, children administered with Tregs were able to maintain higher fasting C-peptide levels, but despite some preliminary evidence pointing to efficacious dose response, the relatively small sample size rules out any robust conclusions. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4fgb0","text":"In this study, two children achieved clinical remission (as defined by DDI ≤0.5 IU/kg, and fasting C-peptide \u003e 0.5 ng/mL 1 year after enrollment) in the higher dose group, in comparison to one child in the lower dose group, but the small sample number prohibits a meaningful dose dependency assessment.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b8d8v","text":"Additionally, 5 of those receiving two doses of Tregs (for a total of 30 x 106 cells/kg BW) achieved remission. In summary, 8 of those in the active treatment arms achieved remission while 2 subjects in the concurrent control groups achieved remission.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":77,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1jjqt","text":"The low dose of 2.5 x 106 cells/kg BW was chosen to provide an approximately 10-fold multiplication factor between the low dose and the high dose group, and to account for the possibility that lower doses may be active, as suggested by the adult study. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":24,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4qo3b","text":"In conclusion, the above safety and preliminary efficacy analyses justify the evaluation of the 2 proposed doses in this study.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"akuvq","text":"Justification for Study Population","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":34}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"35lkf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dhbh1","text":"Adolescent subjects aged 8 to less than 18 years old with recent onset T1DM will be eligible for enrollment in this study. Details of the inclusion and exclusion criteria are included in Step 8.1 and 8.2.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c4k2r","text":"T1DM most commonly presents in childhood with incidence rates increasing from birth, and peaking between 5-7 years of age and at or near puberty.4, 29, 30 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":145,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1l68i","text":"The increasing incidence of T1DM throughout the world is especially marked in young children.31 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":93,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bpsmq","text":"Registries in Europe suggest that recent incident rates of T1DM were highest in the youngest age-group (0-4 years).32 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":115,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7pm7o","text":"Incidence rates decline after puberty and appear to stabilize in young adulthood (15-29 years). Those under the age of 18 are most often afflicted,33 but an approximately equal number of adults over 18 are thought to develop the disease, though incidence in older people receives less media or research attention.34","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":147,"length":2},{"style":"sup","offset":313,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ate45","text":"The T1DM disease course varies from adolescents to adults. Beta-cell destruction in adults appears to occur at a much slower rate than in young T1DM cases, often delaying the need for insulin therapy after diagnosis.35 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":216,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c1g45","text":"Younger adolescents in particular appear to have a more robust and aggressive autoimmune process with more rapid progression to disease and a shorter remission (or honeymoon) phase.36 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":181,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6arcj","text":"Not surprisingly, there have been suggestions of efficacy differences in younger vs. older subjects in clinical studies of anti-CD3 and anti-CD20 mAbs, with higher efficacy trends observed in younger cohorts.37, 38 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":208,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75suk","text":"According to a statement from the ADA, adolescents with T1DM have characteristics and needs that dictate different standards of care from adults with T1DM. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"br7qj","text":"The management of diabetes in adolescents must take into account the major differences between adolescents of various ages and adults.39","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":134,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"et2o1","text":"For example, insulin doses based only on body size are likely to be incorrect; the consequences of hypoglycemic events are distinctly different between adults and adolescents; and risks for diabetic complications are likely influenced by puberty.40 ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":246,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cfvcv","text":"The rationale for studying childern and adolescents is detailed in the Caladrius Biosciences authored document titled “Prospect of Direct Benefit” (reference on file) that was submitted to the FDA in support of the Investigational New Drug (IND) #016232. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fbr2d","text":"As discussed above, there is sufficient evidence from the two Phase 1 studies that autologous ex vivo expanded polyclonal Treg therapy (manufactured comparably or similar to CLBS03) is safe and well tolerated in adults with established T1DM, and in adolescents with new onset T1DM. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d9e92","text":"Additionally, Treg therapy appears to be potentially efficacious especially in adolescents.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5psn1","text":"Taken together, the critical yet unmet medical need in adolescents with new onset T1DM, underpinned by a more aggressive autoimmune process, and with evidence for safety, tolerability, and potential for efficacy in adolescents, support studying the safety and efficacy of CLBS03 in a prospective, randomized, placebo-controlled, exploratory Phase 2 clinical study.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"9lvqn","text":"Objectives","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eq1eh","text":"Primary Objective:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"disup","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"907b5","text":"The primary objective of this study is to assess the safety and potential efficacy of CLBS03 (either of the two doses 2.5 or 20 x 106 cells/kg BW) to modify the T1DM disease course,including preservation of β-cell function and improvements in measures of disease severity, as compared with placebo in adolescents with recent onset T1DM.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":132,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1dqh3","text":"Secondary Objective:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":20}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ffe45","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1knb","text":"The secondary objective is to assess the efficacy of CLBS03, including additional measures of T1DM severity, and to evaluate the effect of CLBS03 on the pathologic autoimmune response underlying T1DM and on the general immune responsiveness through 104 weeks.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"5jh99","text":"Study Endpoints","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"904q8","text":"Primary Efficacy Endpoint","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c95gp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d351f","text":"The primary study endpoint is the 4-hour MMTT-stimulated C-peptide AUC mean at 26 and 52 weeks. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"20i30","text":"Secondary Efficacy Endpoints","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":28}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2s5vl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aftme","text":"Secondary efficacy endpoints include the 2-hour MMTT-stimulated C-peptide AUC mean at 13, 26, 52 and 78 weeks and the 4-hour MMTT-stimulated C-peptide AUC mean at 104 weeks. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"lgt2","text":"Additional metabolic evaluations will include a comparison between the study treatment groups in DDI, severe hypoglycemia, HbA1c, fasting and post-prandial blood glucose levels, and proportion of subjects who achieve partial or complete remission. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5j8uj","text":"Additional information on the secondary efficacy endpoints can be found in Step 37.2. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cgj0a","text":"Safety Endpoints","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":16}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3uk0n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4n4l7","text":"Adverse events, including SAEs and events of special interest (see Section Adverse event reporting and safety monitoring), will be assessed in both treatment arms through week 104. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"asmdd","text":"Proportion of subjects in which the infusion was prematurely stopped or paused because of adverse events will also be assessed for each treatment arm.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"e8h9k","text":"Continuous Glucose Monitoring","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4g47d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a5bh9","text":"Serum glucose data from continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) devices will be examined for a subset of patients who are willing to use a continuous glucose monitoring device and have access to a continuous glucose monitoring device. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4eu0o","text":"As the science of CGM is still evolving and there is no consensus on the best way to examine these data, these analyses are considered exploratory. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cuall","text":"Particular attention will be paid to observations of low and high glucose levels and the pattern of fluctuations in serum glucose over the course of the study.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9f2ae","text":"Exploratory Biomarker Assays","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":28}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dshs4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dro11","text":"Retained biological samples including genetic samples may be utilized to learn more about causes of type 1 diabetes, its complications (such as eye, nerve, and kidney damage) and other conditions for which individuals with diabetes are at increased risk, and how to improve treatment. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"au5u8","text":"Samples may also be utilized to further evaluate those subjects responsive to therapy and to elucidate treatment mechanisms. The results of these future analyses, and any mechanistic studies, will not be made known to the participant. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"64rnl","text":"Retained biological samples will be collected for future analyses according to the schedule of assessments table (Section 4 and step 7.5). The following analyses may be conducted on the retained samples collected:","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3f752","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"408ko","text":"1. Assessment of immune cell subset and intracellular cytokine profile: Cryopreserved peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) will be analyzed using multi-parameter flow cytometry to assess changes in various immune cell subsets following expanded Treg administration. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":2},{"style":"bold","offset":3,"length":68}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fju40","text":"Overall changes in peripheral blood leukocyte composition (B-cell, monocytes, natural killer [NK] cells, T-cells, etc.) will be determined. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vg37","text":"Of particular interest will be the enumeration of activated, naïve, memory, and regulatory T-cell populations as defined by combinations of cell surface markers. Additionally, the intracellular cytokine profile will be assessed via flow cytometry to determine if cytokine expression is altered by the investigational therapy; ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7gacs","text":"for example, a shift in Th subset (Th1, Th2, and Th17) cytokine production. This analysis will include intracellular staining for regulatory cytokines in the regulatory and effector T-cell subsets.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1q6hp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3i1vh","text":"2. Cytokine analysis: Pro-inflammatory cytokines (platelet derived growth factor (PDGF), IL-1ß, Il-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-12, IL-13, IL-33, tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α) and anti-inflammatory cytokines (TGF-ß, IL-10) will be analyzed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"48sh6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9r38n","text":"3. Autoantibody analysis: Key markers of autoimmune processes directed against pancreatic islets include anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD) 65, anti-insulin (IAA), anti-islet cell (ICA)-512/insulinoma antigen (IA)-2, and anti-zinc transporter protein (ZnT)-8 autoantibodies. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":25}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4vkrg","text":"Detection of these autoantibody combinations has proven to be an accurate predictor of T1DM in several natural history studies. Shifts in the immunoglobulin (Ig) isotype titers may indicate a change in the type of T-helper cell responses to the autoantigen. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3bnta","text":"For example, increases in titers of anti-GAD IgE, IgG2, or IgG4 antibodies could indicate a shift to a more regulatory-type profile following Treg infusion. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dmhoq","text":"This study will test the hypothesis that successful treatment will be associated with a reduction in the titer or change in the isotype of diabetes-related autoantibodies.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ca4e","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d01o","text":"4. Whole blood deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) epigenetic studies: DNA purified from whole blood will be used to measure the frequency of Tregs in peripheral blood by means of epigenetic analysis. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":62}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"lcoe","text":"Analysis will be performed using the methylation-sensitive quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) method developed by Epiontis (Berlin, Germany). ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5vmqc","text":"This assay targets the demethylated state of the Treg-specific demethylation region (TSDR) of the FOXP3 gene – a highly specific marker of Tregs. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9lu2j","text":"The proportion of CD4+CD25+CD127lo/-cells determined by flow cytometry strongly correlates with the proportion of demethylation of FOXP3 TSDR measured by qPCR. ","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":21,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":26,"length":1},{"style":"sup","offset":32,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6kkbk","text":"The proportion of demethylated FOXP3 will be normalized to the proportion of demethylated CD3 DNA.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"auv5h","text":"The FOXP3 to CD3 ratio as determined by epigenetic analysis of methylation state strongly correlates with the ratio of Treg to CD3+ cells as measured by flow cytometry.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"sup","offset":130,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5h0fm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6gl38","text":"5. Whole blood human leukocyte antigen (HLA) genotyping: DNA collected from participants will be used to perform sequence-based HLA typing.
